facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1332 of 1968 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 1332 of 1968. Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 3, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 201 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated February 3, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 201 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 3, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 201 of 1963. Mangachari, K. R. Chaudhuri and K. Rajendra Chaudhury, for the appellants.

facts.text: The appeal is by certificate against the judgment of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in a batch of Writ Petitions.

anchor.surface_text: This Appeal is by a Certificate against the Judgment of the Andhra Pradesh High Court giver in a batch of Writ Petitions of which the Writ Petition giving rise to this Appeal was one.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the Writ Petitions and gave certain directions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court while dismissing the Writ Petitions gave certain directions to which we will refer later.

facts.text: Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation of Passengers and Goods Act XVI of 1952 became applicable to the State of Andhra in 1953 and subsequently to Andhra Pradesh in 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras Motor Vehicles  Taxation of Passengers and Goods  Act  Act XVI of 1952  became applicable to the State of Andhra and subsequently to the Andhra Pradesh when the respective reorganisation of States took place in 1953 and 1956.

facts.text: In 1959 the Andhra Pradesh legislature enacted the Motor Vehicles Taxation of Passengers and Goods Andhra Pradesh Amendment Act to augment revenue by increasing rates for state carriages and goods vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: In 1959 the Andhra Pradesh legislature enacted the Motor Vehicles  Taxation of Passengers and Goods  Andhra Pradesh  Amendment  Act with a view to augment the revenue of the State. By this amendment Act the rates had been increased in respect of State carriages as well as in respect of goods vehicles.

facts.text: Government of Andhra Pradesh appointed 8th May 1959 as the date on which the State Act came into force under sub-section 2 of Section 1 of the Amendment Act 1959.

anchor.surface_text: under sub-section  2  of Section 1 of the Madras Motor Vehicle  Taxation of Passengers and Goods  Andhra Pradesh  Amendment  Act 1959, the Govt. of Andhra Pradesh appointed the 8th May 1959 as the date on which the State Act came into force.

facts.text: On 7th May 1959 by G.O. Ms. No. 1077 the State Transport Authority was directed by the Government to fix maximum fares inclusive of the leviable tax for state carriages in areas comprised in State of Andhra before 1st November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On 7th May 1959 by G.O. Ms. No. 1077 the State Transport Authority was directed by the Govt. to fix maximum fares inclusive of the leviable tax under the Act for the 52-1 S. C. India a/71 state carriages in the State of Andhra Pradesh which immediately before the 1st November 1956 were companyprised in the State of Andhra.

facts.text: The Andhra Pradesh Amendment Act was challenged in a batch of Writ Petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh and struck down as unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The Andhra Pradesh Amendment having companye into force it was challenged in a batch of Writ Petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh and that Court had struck down the Act as being unconstitutional.

facts.text: Legislature passed Act 34 of 1961 validating the levy under the struck down Act and imposing surcharge from 3rd November 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The legislature thereafter passed Act 34 of 1961 by- validating the levy under the Act which was struck down by the High Court and also for imposition of surcharge from the different dates from the date on which it came into force namely from the 3rd November 1961.

facts.text: Operators questioned the Amendment Act of 1961 claiming they could not collect fares on enhanced rates due to permit conditions limiting to 7-1/2 pies or 4 NP per passenger per mile and Regional Transport Authorities did not modify the condition.

anchor.surface_text: The operators again questioned the Amendment Act of 1961 on the ground that they had number companylected the fares on the enhanced rates fixed by the Transport Authority because by the companyditions of their permit they were precluded from companylecting the fares at a rate higher than 7-1/2 pies or 4 NP per passenger per mile.

facts.text: High Court negatived the contention of operators, rejected Writ Petitions but directed that Respondents not entitled to collect enhanced surcharge for May 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention was negatived by the High Court which while rejecting the Writ Petitions on that ground numbertheless directed that the Respondents will number be entitled to payment or companylect the enhanced surcharge from the operators for the month of May 1959

facts.text: Operators argued that enhanced surcharge not payable immediately on 1961 Act coming into force without amending permit conditions on fares.

anchor.surface_text: The point which is urged before us, as was urged in the High Court is whether the enhanced surcharge became operative and payable immediately on the companying into force of the 1961 Act or was it necessary to amend the companyditions of the permit

facts.text: Appellants relied on Madhya Pradesh Transport Co. Private Ltd. v. State of Madhya Pradesh to argue fares including taxes cannot be collected without altering fare table.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate for the Appellants argues relying on Madhya Pradesh Transport Co. Private Ltd. v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1  that unless the table of fares is altered in accordance with the procedure laid down fares which includes taxes cannot be lawfully companylected

facts.text: High Court disagreed with Madhya Pradesh case and held G.O. Ms. No. 1077 of 7th May 1959 and RTA proceedings dated 12th May 1959 sufficient to authorize collection of enhanced fares.

anchor.surface_text: This very companytention was raised before the High Court, which disagreeing with the Madhya Pradesh case cited above held that the directions issued by the Govt. in G.O. Ms. No. 1077 of 7th May 1959 persuant to which the Regional Transport Authority by its proceedings dated 12th May 1959

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority by proceedings dated 12th May 1959 called upon Regional Transport Officers to notify operators.

anchor.surface_text: persuant to which the Regional Transport Authority by its proceedings dated 12th May 1959 called upon the Regional Transport Officers to numberify the operators and which the said officers had numberified.

facts.text: Constitutionality of enhanced surcharge upheld by Supreme Court in Nazeeria Motor Service v. State of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: Government issued notification under Section 43(1)(i) of Motor Vehicles Act 1939 directing State Transport Authority to fix maximum fares inclusive of tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Government has persuant to Section 43 issued the following numberification In exercise of the powers companyferred by clause of sub-section  1  of Section 43 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939  Central Act, IV of 1939  and in supersession of the Notification of the Government of A.P.

facts.text: Notification superseded previous notification No. 1184 dated 11th August 1956 published 6th September 1956.

anchor.surface_text: in supersession of the Notification of the Government of A.P. in Public Works and Transport Department No. 1184 dated the 11th August 1956, published at page 2026 of part I of the A. P. Gazette dated the 6th September 1956

facts.text: Regional Transport Officers notified operators to collect enhanced fares in compliance with directions.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the directions given by the Government in the above numberification the Regional Transport Authority called upon the Regional Transport Officers to numberify the operators to companylect the enhanced fares and accordingly the officers companycerned in companypliance with those directions numberified,, the operators.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that notification under Section 43(1)(i) and compliance with Section 44(4) amends permit conditions via Section 59(3)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Once the provisions of Section 43 1  i  and 44 4  are companyplied with Section 59 3  c  companyes into play and it has the effect of incorporating the maximum fares as numberified including the tax leviable, as a companydition of the permit.

facts.text: In Madhya Pradesh case, no notification under Section 43 was issued and Section 59(3)(c) not considered.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the madhya Pradesh case is clearly distin- guishable as it does number appear that any numberification was issued under Section 43 as was done in this case number do we find that the provisions of Section 59 3  c  have been referred to or companysidered.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 3, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 201 of 1963.

issues.text: whether the enhanced surcharge became operative and payable immediately on the coming into force of the 1961 Act or was it necessary to amend the conditions of the permit dealing with the fares leviable by the operators before the Government could collect the enhanced surcharge from them

anchor.surface_text: The point which is urged before us, as was urged in the High Court is whether the enhanced surcharge became operative and payable immediately on the companying into force of the 1961 Act or was it necessary to amend the companyditions of the permit dealing with the fares leviable by the operators before the Government companyld companylect the enhanced surcharge from them.

issues.text: whether there is an impediment to the operators to collect fares without the conditions of the permit being amended

anchor.surface_text: A.I.R. Vol. 49 1962-M. P. 108. It may be mentioned that the companystitutionality of the enhanced surcharge was upheld by this Court in Nazeeria Motor Service etc etc. v. State of Andhra Pradesh Anr. 1 and therefore the only question that servives is whether there is an impediment to the operators to companylect fares without the companyditions of the permit being amended.

issues.text: whether the payment of the enhanced tax is dependent on the operators collecting the enhanced fares

anchor.surface_text: There is of course the other basic question whether the payment of the enhanced tax is dependent on the operators companylecting the enhanced fares. In any case it is unnecessary to companysider this question in the view we have taken that the companytention urged by the Appellant is unsustainable.

issues.text: whether the directions issued by the Govt. in G.O. Ms. No. 1077 of 7th May 1959 pursuant to which the Regional Transport Authority authorised collection of enhanced fares was sufficient authorisation as if the fare tables had been amended

anchor.surface_text: This very contention was raised before the High Court, which disagreeing with the Madhya Pradesh case cited above held that the directions issued by the Govt. in G.O. Ms. No. 1077 of 7th May 1959 persuant to which the Regional Transport Authority by its proceedings dated 12th May 1959 called upon the Regional Transport Officers to notify the operators and which the said officers had notified. authorising them to collect the enhanced fares was sufficient authorisation for them to collect the enhanced fares as if the fare tables had been amended.

arguments.court_reasoning: Relevant provisions of MV Act clearly support the High Court view.

arguments.claim: Notification issued by Government under Section 43(1)(i) statutorily amends conditions of permit by virtue of Section 59(3)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act clearly support the view taken by the High Court that once a Notification is issued by the Government in exercise of the powers under Section 43 1 i the conditions of the permit stand statutorily amended by virtue of Section 59 3 c .

arguments.claim: Compliance with Sections 43(1)(i) and 44(4) activates Section 59(3)(c), incorporating maximum fares notified (inclusive of tax) as condition of permit.

anchor.surface_text: Once the provisions of Section 43 1 i and 44 4 are complied with Section 59 3 c comes into play and it has the effect of incorporating the maximum fares as notified including the tax leviable, as a condition of the permit.

arguments.claim: Madhya Pradesh Transport Co. case clearly distinguishable because no notification under Section 43 issued there and provisions of Section 59(3)(c) not referred to or considered.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the madhya Pradesh case is clearly distin- guishable as it does not appear that any notification was issued under Section 43 as was done in this case nor do we find that the provisions of Section 59 3 c have been referred to or considered.

holdings.text: Once a notification is issued by the Government in exercise of the powers under Section 43(1)(i) the conditions of the permit stand statutorily amended by virtue of Section 59(3)(c)

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act clearly support the view taken by the High Court that once a Notification is issued by the Government in exercise of the powers under Section 43 1  i  the companyditions of the permit stand statutorily amended by virtue of Section 59 3  c . The provisions of Section 43, 44, 48 and 59 before their amendment in 1969, in so far as they are applicable to the matter under companysideration are as follows.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relevant provisions of Sections 43, 44, 48, and 59 of Motor Vehicles Act support High Court view through direct textual application

holdings.text: Once the provisions of Section 43(1)(i) and 44(4) are complied with Section 59(3)(c) comes into play and incorporates the maximum fares as notified including the tax leviable, as a condition of the permit

anchor.surface_text: Once the provisions of Section 43 1  i  and 44 4  are companyplied with Section 59 3  c  companyes into play and it has the effect of incorporating the maximum fares as numberified including the tax leviable, as a companydition of the permit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory sequence: government notification under 43(1)(i), STA directions under 44(4), automatic incorporation via 59(3)(c)

holdings.text: There is no justification for the contention that the collection by the operators of the enhanced fares without the table of fares being amended would entail the cancellation of the permits

anchor.surface_text: This being the legal position we do number think there is any justification for the companytention that the companylection by the operators of the enhanced fares without the table of fares being amended would entail the cancellation of the permits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal position under MV Act sections precludes permit cancellation due to statutory amendment of conditions

holdings.text: The decision of the Madhya Pradesh case is clearly distinguishable as it does not appear that any notification was issued under Section 43 as was done in this case nor do we find that the provisions of Section 59(3)(c) have been referred to or considered

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the madhya Pradesh case is clearly distin- guishable as it does number appear that any numberification was issued under Section 43 as was done in this case number do we find that the provisions of Section 59 3  c  have been referred to or companysidered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent lacks key elements present here: no S.43 notification and no consideration of S.59(3)(c)

holdings.text: The directions issued by the Govt. in G.O. Ms. No. 1077 of 7th May 1959 pursuant to which the Regional Transport Authority by its proceedings dated 12th May 1959 authorised collection of enhanced fares was sufficient authorisation as if the fare tables had been amended

anchor.surface_text: This very companytention was raised before the High Court, which disagreeing with the Madhya Pradesh case cited above held that the directions issued by the Govt. in G.O. Ms. No. 1077 of 7th May 1959 persuant to which the Regional Transport Authority by its proceedings dated 12th May 1959 called upon the Regional Transport Officers to numberify the operators and which the said officers had numberified. authorising them to companylect the enhanced fares was sufficient authorisation for them to companylect the enhanced fares as if the fare tables had been amended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court view supported by MV Act provisions and factual compliance with notifications and proceedings

precedents.citation: Madhya Pradesh Transport Co. Private Ltd. v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate for the Appellants argues relying on Madhya Pradesh Transport Co. Private Ltd. v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1  that unless the table of fares is altered in accordance with the procedure laid down fares which includes taxes cannot be lawfully companylected and therefore they are number law bound to pay the enhanced surcharge. This very companytention was raised before the High Court, which disagreeing with the Madhya Pradesh case cited above held that the directions issued by the Govt. in G.O. Ms. No. 1077 of 7th May 1959 persuant to which the Regional Transport Authority by its proceedings dated 12th May 1959 called upon the Regional Transport Officers to numberify the operators and which the said officers had numberified. authorising them to companylect the enhanced fares was sufficient authorisation for them to companylect the enhanced fares as if the fare tables had been amended. A.I.R.  Vol. 49  1962-M. P. 108.
